summary: Strategic, data-driven, innovative, and empowering Servant HR professional leader with a proven track record in managing end-to-end HR operations.  Adept at implementing innovative HR solutions, I aim to enhance organizational effectiveness, promote a positive work culture, and align HR practices with overall business objectives. Eager comprehensive skills in HR management, data integrity, and employee development to a forward-thinking team, contributing to the organization's overall success.

currentPositions.description:
Alzheimer’s Disease Cooperative Study (ADCS)
The ADCS was formed in 1991 as a cooperative agreement between the National Institute on Aging  (NIA) and the University of California, San Diego. The ADCS is a major initiative for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) clinical studies in the Federal Government, addressing treatments for both cognitive and behavioral symptoms. The ADCS is part of the NIA Division of Neuroscience’s effort to facilitate the discovery, development, and testing of new drugs for the treatment of AD and is part of the Alzheimer’s Disease Prevention Initiative as well.

message.text:
Such a reality when you see problems , share them, and the response you get “well, we will handle if it happens again.” 

In most my career I’ve seen professionals say that HR or not HR. This is the very essence of reactive vs proactive. It’s important to create a space and listen to the ones doing the day to day work. If this is something you don’t have, create it. 

It’s more than just 1:1 conversations and team meetings. Embed a psychological safety/ safe to speak environment so that this happens. If you find that you’re putting our a lot of fires, then it’s time to think about what space and culture you created.

There are 2 Types of HR Departments in 2024

1️⃣ Reactive, Barely hanging on for dear life.
2️⃣ Proactive, Focusing on preventing problems before they start.

Most are in Type 1, Is yours one of them?

REACTIVE HR
❌ Denies mistakes and shifts blame. 
❌ Avoids feedback or ignores feedback if given. 
❌ Always reacting to problems, never anticipating them. 
❌ Dropping the ball on clear and consistent communication. 
❌ Constant putting out fires NO time for long-term planning. 
❌ Enforcing rules to the letter creating a rigid and unsupportive environment.

PROACTIVE HR
✅ Future-Focused, Proactively Planning to prevent problems before they happen. 
✅ Owns mistakes and works to correct. 
✅ Actively seeking feedback for continuous improvement. 
✅ Transparency and clear communication. 
✅ Collaboration with other departments to DRIVE business success. 
✅ Invest in employee development and building a thriving work environment.

Is your department PROACTIVE?

Are you ACTIVELY taking steps to make your department PROACTIVE?

#HR #HumanResources #Proactive #Leadership #HRDeparment #StrategicHR #FutureOfWork #EmployeeEngagement #TalentAcquisition

Such a powerful woman and advocate for the LGBtQ+ community! I’ve been so lucky to have befriend Christynne. ❤️ 

I’m so honored for my friendship that I was able to have her speak at last years Health HR PRIDE at Work event.

Dear Pride Family,

Around this time last year, San Diego was making news around the country, because of a so-called “controversy” perpetuated by right-wing media. A young girl cried wolf- calling against the right of a trans woman to use the women's locker room. Right-wing media stirred itself up into a national frenzy that eventually led to heated protests and a dramatic Santee City Council meeting about who should and shouldn’t be allowed to use public locker rooms. 

The initial news media didn’t name the transgender woman in question, but she came forward to address the mischaracterizations and stand up for her community.  Christynne (Chrissy) Lili Wrene Wood came forward as the Black transgender woman in the locker room and invited supporters to stand up with her.  At the time that her presence and identity were suddenly called into question, she had been taking that same YMCA aqua aerobics class for years. 

Chrissy recently told her story –– in her own words, in the Union-Tribune. She reminded us of the weight of the anti-Blackness buried in this allegation and controversy, drawing a clear line between this incident - when the words of a young white girl questioned this Black woman’s right to be in the same locker room - to the events preceding the lynching of Emmett Till in 1955. 

This not-so-distant history was on many of our minds, and as we’re making our history now, we’re also changing the story we tell about Black trans folks. This includes writing new endings about how we as a community show up for our Black siblings. In this case, Chrissy’s community showed up in force, led with love, strength and joy by Chrissy herself. 

In the face of considerable hate and controversy, Chrissy maintained strength and never lost her joy.  She infused unwavering faith into the community rallied around her. In 2023, San Diego Pride presented her with the Spirit of Stonewall Champion of Pride Award for her indisputable status as an icon and a pillar in our community.

As we hit the midpoint of Women’s History Month, we invite you to join us in celebrating the women who are making history now with us. We have so many trans and queer women in our community who transform the fear and hate they face into love, who create spaces for queer and trans joy and celebration. They stare down transphobia and racism and feel called to take action to protect not only themselves but their communities. 

I call on my fellow white folks and non Black people of color to actively appreciate the Black folks and Black women in your circles. Search for ways you can pick up some of the burden of fighting homophobia and transphobia. 

Thank you, Chrissy, and thank you to all the trans, lesbian, bisexual, and queer Black women and women of color that are making history now.  

With Pride, 

Jen Hibberts (she/they)
Organizing & Outreach Coordinator

commentary.text:
We have to leverage this example. We need to be proactive but have the skillset to implement effective change management practices to be reactive. 
I found in my career, that the professionals doing the day to day job have all ideas. The culture of the organization or department needs create a space for concerns that truly listens and creates solutions. 
If you’re putting out more fires, then take it back to first root of it all.
